essay: As I read the news article about tourists hurting the polar bears, I feel a mix of anger and sadness in my heart. It's utterly dreadful that humans can intentionally cause harm to innocent animals and still have a good night's sleep. In my opinion, people should not even be in close proximity to polar bears. These creatures deserve to be left alone in their natural habitat.

Upon learning about the suffering inflicted upon the people of Venezuela, especially the children who are left famished and bewildered, my heart overflows with compassion. However, my emotional response quickly changes when I ponder the underlying causes of this situation. The country possesses vast wealth from its oil reserves but has been stripped of its resources due to the corrupt practices of communism. My anger and disgust are directed towards the centralized government that perpetuates an environment that only benefits a select group of treacherous officials. The inherent flaws within such a governing system rapidly give way to corruption and abuse, as is evident in the current catastrophic situation in Venezuela. A decentralized system is more transparent as it ensures accountability for those in power, making it easier to prevent them from committing misdeeds. I deeply regret that this crisis in Venezuela is not limited to its borders, but has become a global concern of our own.

The current situation in this conflict seems complicated and messy, yet I find myself struggling to feel invested. In my view, these individuals are hardly civilized and it doesn't matter whether the Houthis or civilians become casualties. Those who behave immorally deserve what they get. I understand that the Houthis have constitutional support from Iran, but I'm clearly in favor of the coalition because this is essentially a battle between Iran and those who are relatively better than them (which, let's be real, isn't saying much). However, I believe that if one is to go to war, they should be prepared to do whatever it takes to achieve victory. This includes the killing of civilians. If your intention isn't to win, why even bother? And in the case of Yemen, rather than merely meddling, we should annihilate the entire country and allow the rightful government to restore order.

After reading about the heartbreaking deaths of innocent children due to their parent's reckless drug use, I am overcome with anger. The sheer notion that any parent would intentionally subject their children to toxic substances is simply unfathomable, showcasing a complete disregard for the wellbeing of their loved ones. This callous behavior represents a complete dereliction of responsibility, as parents are morally obligated to protect their children from harm. It is crucial for parents to take preemptive measures to prevent their children from accessing dangerous drugs, and remain vigilant to identify any potential risks that may imperil their safety. The agony and trauma endured by these young children owing to the irresponsibility and negligence of others is intolerable and must not be condoned.

Upon reading the article, I was overcome with a sense of anger towards the inhumane treatment of animals by some humans. It is disheartening to think that such actions can be taken without any regard for the well-being of other living beings on this planet. We, as humans, need to be more mindful of our actions and the impact they have on the environment and the inhabitants that share it with us. It is our responsibility to take care of all living beings, not just ourselves.

After completing the article on UW-Madison, I feel a mix of anger and sadness. The details of the alleged attacks on five women by Alec Cook are disturbing. The article sheds light on how he forced these women into non-consensual sexual encounters, either by drugging or physically overpowering them, despite their desperate pleas to stop. Such incidents are prevalent in our culture, and it's disheartening to read about them. It's upsetting to consider that people like Cook could roam free for an extended period, hurting and traumatizing innocent individuals. Additionally, his legal team has a lot to refute, which indicates the potential challenges and uncertainty in getting justice for the women Cook allegedly victimized.

The cruelty inflicted upon innocent animals is utterly heartbreaking. It is despicable how humans relentlessly capture and enslave these vulnerable creatures, denying them the basic care they require. One cannot help but feel both sad and outraged by such a wicked situation. The question that arises is why people are so callous? If we are unable to provide these animals with the care that they need and deserve, we must learn to leave them be in their natural habitats. It is not fair to dominate and destroy everything that Mother Nature has given us. It is high time we recognize the repercussions of our actions and strive to do better.

The idea that wars can be fought without civilian casualties baffles me. War is an inherently grim and messy business; there's no 'polite' way to wage it. If you want to win, you have to fight dirty and fight hard. World War 2 wasn't won by 'playing nice' â€“ we had to resort to nuclear weapons and level Germany. Civilians are an inevitable part of the equation. In Yemen, the decision to allow rebel groups supported by Iran to take over has put innocent citizens in danger and resulted in threats to Saudi Arabia. The notion that the Saudis should prioritize protecting the Yemeni over their own citizens is ridiculous. They should fight with everything they have, regardless of the consequences. Winning the war is what matters, not sparing people's feelings. This kind of naive thinking is dangerous.

The EPA's failure to impose fines on violators is infuriating. It sends the message that breaking rules has no consequences, thereby empowering offenders to inflict harm without accountability. This exemplifies the government's disregard for its duties, wasting resources without resolution. I firmly advocate for annual restructuring of every government division to rectify these flaws. Clean water is swiftly becoming a precious resource, compelling the need to safeguard it.

Upon learning about the harm inflicted upon a person or a group, my emotions are consumed with an intense anger. It is beyond reprehensible that any individual or community should experience such atrocities. Those who committed these heinous acts must be held accountable for their actions, and swift justice must be served. Ignoring these injustices will only perpetuate the cycle of violence and suffering. It is our duty to speak out and demand that immediate and concrete actions are taken to put a conclusive end to this brutality.

Upon reading this article, I cannot help but feel an immense amount of anger. The notion that women are still subjected to such oppressive standards in this day and age is truly infuriating. It is unacceptable that a woman requires the validation of a man in order to pursue her own desires. In this day and age, everyone should be granted the freedom to do as they please without constraints or limitations. This injustice must come to an end.

In my opinion, this type of situation is more of a disgraceful and enraging rather than simply saddening. It's distressing to think that adolescents are so easily influenced and engrossed in the online world to the point of losing themselves. It's crucial for parents to step up and ensure their children live in reality, and equip them with the tools to be responsible and resilient. Unfortunately, in Russia, this can be a challenge as there is a prevalent issue with parents not being capable caregivers due to alcoholism, which tragically often leads to youth suicides. Personally, I cannot fathom someone being so weak and vulnerable to the extent that they would be coerced to take their own life due to something read online. Although I do not consider myself to be an extremely strong person, this idea remains completely foreign to me.

The participant's response reveals a deep-seated anger after reading the news article about harm caused to an individual or group. Upon examining the case closely, they are baffled at how the roommate managed to hide the facts for an extended period. Additionally, the accuser's intentions are called into question, thereby casting doubt on the credibility of the entire #metoo movement. The commentator's view on the issue is clearly one of personal outrage.

Upon reading the news article, I was overcome with a surge of anger and disgust. To discover that such atrocities are still occurring in our contemporary world is truly disheartening. The reality that certain nations must send in troops to aid others is a sorrowful indication that our society is not quite as progressive as we may have believed. The recent decision made by Kenya to extradite an official and knowingly place their life in peril if returned to Sudan left me appalled. This cruel and detestable action can only be described as a tragedy, and Kenya should feel ashamed for their involvement in this situation.

Upon reading the news article, I concur with the individual's actions in shooting the dog, as it was justified given the woman's blatant disregard for the safety of others through her gross negligence. Her decision to allow her unleashed dog to freely run in the park posed a clear threat to the public. Despite the man's repeated requests and warning, the woman still ignored his pleas. The sight of dogs running unrestrained and causing harm to innocent individuals triggers anger within me. It is imperative that authorities take serious action and enforce measures to put an end to this dangerous behavior.

Upon reading the article, a strong surge of surprise and anger overtook me. To think that a parent could display such blatant indifference towards their own child is simply appalling. I'm left with a profound feeling of shame upon hearing this news. The mother's account of the incident, in which she claims the child had been sleeping for an hour prior, doesn't seem credible and fails to justify the catastrophic outcome. The magnitude of this heinous conduct is disconcerting, and it leaves me completely bewildered.

The senseless attacks and killings of individuals based on their religion, race or sexuality fills me with anger. It's frustrating that people are unable to appreciate and accept differences. The impact of Trump's words is evident and alarming, as they seem to condone such violence against minorities. From my perspective, he is the problem instead of the solution.

Upon reading this article, my anger flares up as I vehemently disagree with the perspective presented. The article blames Trump for any wrongdoing against Israel, yet this accusation is unfounded. In actuality, Trump has been a strong supporter of Israel, unlike his predecessor Obama, who not only failed to aid Israel but even formed an alliance with its sworn enemy, Iran. It is unjust to hold Trump responsible for any increase in anti-Semitic sentiment. Instead, he is merely a reflection of the necessary cultural changes that have been long overdue. The 2016 pushback from white men can be attributed to the constant bombardment of the LGBTQ+ community, minorities, and women. Our issues surpass Trump's presidency, and we must tackle them accordingly. Thus, I welcome you to the resistance.

After reading the news article, I cannot deny that the heart-wrenching story is a sad reality in third-world countries where people sell fuel at the roadside. It is frustrating to acknowledge that tragedies like this happen all too often, and the scale of the world's enormity is beyond comprehension. Although I sympathize with the grieving families, I find it challenging to connect emotionally with the victims, who were unknown to me until their untimely death. To me, their existence seems like pages from a storybook that are detached from reality. Despite society's expectations, I do not believe that learning about these deaths makes the world a better place.

The ongoing struggles that Haiti faces are truly heartbreaking. It seems as if this nation is constantly plagued by tragedy - from the destructive hurricanes to the recurring outbreaks of cholera. Although I deeply respect Bill and Melinda Gates for their acknowledgement of the importance of vaccines in preventing diseases like cholera, it is disheartening to learn that Haitians hold incorrect beliefs about their effectiveness. The unavailability of vaccines puts us at high risk of lethal infections such as smallpox, measles, and cholera. It's difficult to stomach the fact that so many people are desperately in need of these life-saving tools, yet they are simply out of reach.

The article is deeply unsettling, and I feel a strong sense of anger towards the parents who allowed such heinous acts to be committed against their own child. I hope the young girl is able to overcome her traumas and grow into a kind and decent person despite the horrors she had to endure. The fact that anyone could subject a minor to such horrors is truly unconscionable, and I believe the parents should be held accountable for their actions with a maximum sentence of life imprisonment or even the death penalty. The gravity of their actions cannot be understated, and the justice system must ensure that such atrocities are not tolerated. Despite the disturbing nature of this story, I hold onto hope that justice will be served and the girl will be able to heal from her traumatic experiences.

Upon reading the news of Burmese killing Muslims, it's only understandable to feel a strong sense of anger. Of course, nobody wants terrorists to roam around freely, creating trouble in their own country. However, suggesting the expulsion of an entire Muslim community is not only extreme but also unfair. It's essential to assist Burma, but not at the expense of trampling on human rights or promoting hatred towards a particular group. Instead, we must seek peaceful resolutions and treat everyone with the dignity they deserve.

The individuals responsible for causing harm are truly despicable. It's infuriating that some parents feel compelled to send their children away in order to secure work. This reactionary approach not only lacks foresight, but also exploits their own flesh and blood. These kids possess boundless potential, but without proper education, it's all wasted.

Hey Nora, have you read the article about the handler that left his police dog, Lina to die in a hot car in Arkansas? The dog had served the sheriff's office for three years and was important for drug investigations. Lina was unfortunately left in the car for 38 hours and the handler is on paid administrative leave while an investigation is underway. It's shocking that someone could forget a big police dog in a car for that long without noticing. The disregard shown for animals and humans in society is truly incomprehensible to me. We have lost too many innocent lives, including 82 children this year alone. I am deeply disturbed and angry about this situation. I refuse to accept any excuses that are given for such negligence.

The imbalance in nature has been tinkered with, once again, leaving innocent animals helpless to make room for our own desires. It is revolting to know that our success has come at the expense of defenceless creatures. Despite living in fear like us, their lives are deemed as insignificant because it doesn't generate profits. It's difficult to turn a blind eye to this unyielding truth, and it should be even more challenging. What kind of world are we living in where our avarice triumphs over the wellbeing of all creatures? This reality is maddening.

I am deeply troubled by the news of numerous innocent lives lost due to airstrikes. It is heart-wrenching to witness the deaths of not only military personnel, but also vulnerable children and infants. The gravity of the situation demands swift action to prevent further loss of life. I feel immense anger and disgust toward those responsible for causing such immense suffering to the affected individuals and families. It is imperative that appropriate steps are taken to bring an end to this tragic situation.

Upon reading news articles involving harm to individuals or groups, the participants' responses exude a strong sense of anger. One participant, in particular, expressed an exhaustion with the recurrent pattern of violence, specifically in cases where a police officer uses force and it suddenly becomes acceptable for others to respond with violence or looting. The individual observed a trend where society immediately places all blame on officers without waiting for all the facts, painting them as looking for any chance to use force. The person felt that the public doesn't react the same way when officers themselves are attacked. It's high time to afford both sides of the situation a fair representation.

Upon reading the news article detailing the inhumane treatment of animals within the confines of a zoo, my emotions of anger and disgust are deeply stirred. It is beyond unacceptable to subject wildlife to such deplorable conditions, especially when we have humans living on the streets struggling to survive. It is clear that our society is to blame for the suffering inflicted upon both animals and humans. Our selfish and thoughtless actions have resulted in the imposition of sanctions upon other nations, effectively branding ourselves as the bullies of the world who demand obedience or else face the consequences of our wrath. It is high time that we take responsibility for our actions and begin making the changes necessary to rectify the damage done.

In light of the news of harm inflicted upon a person or a group, I cannot help but feel an overwhelming sense of anger. It is unacceptable that individuals or entire communities should be subjected to such atrocities. The perpetrators must be held accountable for their actions, and justice must be pursued with utmost urgency. We cannot afford to turn a blind eye to these injustices, as it will only perpetuate the cycle of violence and suffering. It is imperative that we take a stand and demand that concrete actions be taken to put an end to these heinous acts.

The behavior of this individual disgusts and angers me deeply. Their attempt to minimize their actions by alleging consent and blaming their victims is incomprehensible. It is absurd for them to suggest that their conviction was solely due to the news articles, when in fact it was their own repugnant behavior. It is unacceptable to cause harm to others for one's own gratification. I am thankful that someone had the courage to speak up and put an end to this individual's harmful actions against women. While it can be difficult to ascertain the truth in certain situations, the number of women who have come forward makes it almost impossible to deny that this individual poses a danger to society. In my opinion, they should be imprisoned for a significant amount of time.

The enduring challenges faced by Haiti are truly gut-wrenching. This nation appears to be plagued by tragedy constantly, whether it's destructive hurricanes or recurring outbreaks of cholera. While I admire Bill and Melinda Gates for acknowledging the significance of vaccines in preventing diseases like cholera, it's saddening to discover that Haitians harbor misconceptions about their efficacy. Due to the absence of these vaccines, our risk of fatal infections, such as smallpox, measles, and cholera, is alarmingly high. It's unbearable to accept that a large number of people desperately require these life-saving tools, yet they are unattainable.

I am deeply frustrated by the fact that our oceans are being polluted, and this problem is resulting in the harm of innocent animals. The notion that something as simple as plastic floating in the ocean can cause harm to sea birds is both absurd and understandable. It is maddening that humans are constantly causing harm to things that should have never been tampered with in the first place. The damage that our trash is causing fills me with anger and sadness.

After reading the article, I felt an intense anger towards the cruel and heartless treatment of animals by some humans. It's overwhelmingly sad to realize that such atrocious acts can be committed without any consideration for the welfare of other living beings that coexist with us on this planet. It's crucial for us, as human beings, to be conscious of our actions and how they shape the environment and its inhabitants. It's our duty to protect all creatures great and small, and not just worry about ourselves.

After reading the article, I was filled with a strong sense of anger. The idea that a father could consciously take away the lives of his own children is beyond comprehension. Such an appalling and abominable act can only be carried out by someone who has lost touch with reality. I am left wondering whether the individual responsible is suffering from a severe mental disorder or has been influenced by mind-altering substances.

In light of recent news articles highlighting harm to individuals or groups, I was left feeling disgusted by the actions of men in powerful positions. It's alarming that they choose to use their status as a means to attack women, thinking they can get away with it without consequence. Unfortunately, such stories are becoming increasingly common, underscoring the need to educate people earlier on about sexual assault and appropriate behaviour. Moreover, we require programs and resources that empower women to speak out against perpetrators, ensuring they are held accountable so that such behavior does not recur. The affected women were trapped by their abusers' positions of power, and I can only imagine the trauma they must have experienced. No one deserves to suffer through something like this and no one should have to endure it alone. It is crucial that we never sweep such incidents under the rug or place the blame on the victims.

Upon reading the article that exposes the brutal and savage actions towards animals in a zoo, I find myself overcome with a potent blend of anger and disgust. It is utterly unacceptable to deliberate innocents to such cruelty and agony, especially when we as human beings deal with our own challenges every day. Our community must assume accountability for both animal and human suffering. Our irresponsible and egoistic actions have led other countries to regard us as bullies that demand outright obedience or suffer the consequences of our wrath. We must acknowledge the repercussions of our missteps and act decisively to rectify the situation. It is vital that we implement restorative innovations to repair the harm inflicted.

I strongly believe that incidents like this highlight the urgent need for police to undergo better training. It is crucial, just like how we need water to survive, that law enforcement personnel undergo the best possible training. It is simply unacceptable for a police officer to resort to physical violence, especially when targeting a woman's face. I am angry that I have to repeat this sentiment time and time again, but the repeated occurrence of such incidents cannot continue.

Upon reading news articles about ethnic and religious conflicts, civilian displacement, violent extremist actions, and government crackdowns, my heart is filled with anger and frustration. These issues are overwhelming and yet, I still feel detached from them. I understand that protecting citizens and maintaining autonomy falls within a nation's obligation, and these concerns should be addressed internally. However, I cannot help but be infuriated by the UN's interventionism in such matters. Their involvement seems self-serving and pointless. The UN's tendency to criticize and scrutinize a government's actions for being too strict or not doing enough regarding perceived threats disregards the bigger picture. I am perplexed how the UN can ignore a government's right to protect their people from real and existential threats, while focusing solely on superficial moral reasons to provide shelter to migrants. The UN's inactivity in addressing these issues appears pretentious and self-righteous, and it is exacerbating my anger towards them.

The incidents of harm to individuals or groups that are reported in the news are not something that deeply concerns me. It is clear that these actions are unfair and should be held accountable, but I can't find it in myself to be emotionally invested. I do understand, however, the anger felt towards Islamic terrorism, which has taken innocent American lives. It cannot be denied that Islam is complicit in such acts, with some members harboring violent sentiments even if they don't actively support terrorism. Sadly, not enough voices within the Muslim community condemn such actions or work to prevent them, whether it's at home or abroad. We are essentially waging battle, whether we acknowledge it or not, and this dangerous enemy is not a faceless 'them', but rather something that directly affects you and me. Right now, we must recognize the threat posed by Islam and take decisive actions to curb it.

After reading the news article, a wave of anger and disgust washed over me. Learning that such incidents still happen in our modern world is deeply upsetting. The fact that some countries need to send troops to help others is a sad indication that our society isn't as progressive as we might want to think. I was utterly shocked by Kenya's recent move to extradite an official, knowing full well that the person would be at risk of death if returned to Sudan. This heartless and despicable act is nothing short of a tragedy, and Kenya ought to be ashamed of themselves for their participation in this situation.

I am appalled to learn that someone would callously throw a majestic and colorful bird like a flamingo onto the ground. It's hard to fathom the extent of cruelty that some people are capable of. It would be heartbreaking to witness the demise of such a beautiful creature. I strongly believe that the perpetrator should face severe punishment and be taught a valuable lesson in empathy and respect for all living beings.

After reading the news article, my emotions are simply overwhelmed with anger and sadness. The reported incident is gut-wrenching and utterly heartbreaking. It's beyond my comprehension why someone would want to take the lives of innocent individuals, especially their own family. The man in question should have sought professional help if he was struggling to cope with the loss of his wife. The fact that he resorted to this terrible path is unforgivable. The perpetrator not only robbed his innocent children of the chance to live their lives, but also acted in a manner beyond any human morality. Coping with the immense anger and sadness that comes with such incidents requires immense courage. The accused deserves nothing but contempt, and my heart goes out to the wife and children who have to bear the brunt of such a heinous act.

The frustration in this commentary is palpable. While the claim is scrutinized from both sides, the delay in the roommate's disclosure is perplexing. The participant is doubtful of some women's motivations for coming forth with allegations, which detracts from the credibility of the #metoo movement. The source is just expressing two cents on the matter.

Upon reading the news about the brutal killing of Muslims in Burma, it's normal to experience a strong emotion of anger. Although it's necessary to prevent terrorist activities from harming the country, forcibly evicting an entire Muslim community is an extreme and unfair measure. Instead of compromising the fundamental human rights or encouraging prejudice against any particular group, we must emphasize peaceful and justifiable approaches and treat every individual with dignity. While providing aid and support to Burma is essential, it should not be at the expense of mistreating innocent people. It's imperative that we find solutions that prioritize the well-being and respect of all individuals involved.

Upon reading the aforementioned article, an overwhelming feeling of anger and surprise engulfed me. It is truly deplorable that a parent could be so neglectful towards their own child, leaving me feeling a sense of shame. The excuse provided by the mother, stating that the child was put to bed an hour before the incident, appears unlikely and insubstantial considering the tragic outcome. The sheer magnitude of this appalling incident is disturbing and truly shocking.

The news of this incident is truly heartbreaking and devastating. It is beyond selfish to take the lives of innocent people, especially one's own family. If this man was struggling with a breakdown after losing his wife, he should have sought professional help to work through his issues with her. His children, who were innocent, were denied their right to life. This act was not only ungodly, but also cowardly, and leaves me at a loss for words. The emotions that come to mind are anger towards the perpetrator and immense sorrow for the wife and kids.

Upon reading the news article, a wave of anger and disgust washed over me. It's disheartening to know that such atrocities are still prevalent in our contemporary world. It's a sorrowful indication that our society is not progressing as we believed. Recently, Kenya's decision to extradite an official and knowingly put their life in danger by sending them back to Sudan is appalling. This cruel and detestable action can only be described as tragic, and Kenya should feel ashamed for their involvement in this situation.

It's astounding that Islamic terrorism still persists. Kidnapping innocent individuals and exploiting them as human shields is an outrageous tactic. I'm completely taken aback that this heinous act is ongoing. There must be more measures taken to combat this issue. This never-ending war seems bleak and insurmountable. What action can be taken to bring an end to this plight is uncertain. The whole situation is illogical and inconceivable.

It is worrisome to witness police officers abusing their power without facing any consequences. It's alarming to learn that some of them resort to taking steroids to increase their aggression. It's no wonder that a lot of people harbor resentment towards them. It's unacceptable and frustrating that law enforcement officials display incompetence and lack the necessary intelligence to do their job well. The authorities should take measures to provide better training for police officers, to rectify this behavior, and to address the understandable anger felt towards them.

The fact that the ride was not shut down and properly investigated really infuriates me. My heart breaks for the individuals who lost their lives as a result of this negligence. The thought of the daughter having to witness her mother's tragic death on a ride that was meant to be a source of joy is absolutely heartbreaking. I cannot fathom how she will be able to recover from such a traumatic experience. The entire situation is truly saddening.

Upon reading the news articles, I am overwhelmed with compassion for the victims who have suffered as a result of the despicable act. Simultaneously, my disgust towards radical Islam escalates. It is disheartening to witness that regions affiliated with radical Islam are frequently plagued with such incidents. Despite my optimism for a possible resolution to thwart such abhorrent acts, the brutal truth is that they are probable to persist.

After reading the news articles, I feel a strong sense of empathy towards the victims who have been affected by the heinous act. At the same time, my disgust towards radical Islam intensifies. It's distressing to see that areas associated with radical Islam often face such incidents. Although I remain hopeful for a solution to prevent such appalling acts, the harsh reality is that they are likely to continue.

The global push towards gender equality has been far from fluent in Saudi Arabia, and it is high time to amend it. The requirement for women to attain permission from a male guardian to travel overseas is despicable, to say the least. It goes against the basic human rights, as women are self-reliant individuals and deserve to have complete autonomy over their travel plans. It seems like an ancient belief from the bygone era and should be abandoned right away. My feelings of disgust towards this unfair and unjust practice cannot be put into words.

Did you hear about the Paris attack in the news? It's truly heartbreaking to read about the horrors that occurred and it evokes a deep sense of sorrow for the current state of our world. Prior to this incident, I held the belief that individuals held a mixture of good and bad, but this atrocity has caused me to re-think my viewpoint. It's revolting and unacceptable that someone or a group could commit such a heinous act. The problem of terrorism urgently requires resolution, but it begs the question as to how we can respond effectively without igniting further acts of terror.

It's truly shameful what's happening. The war on terror seems to have failed tremendously, with soldiers losing their lives. The thought of families losing their loved ones is heartbreaking. Additionally, the situation in the Middle East is just as disheartening, with young kids and teenagers being exploited as pawns in a twisted game. Women are being objectified and treated as nothing more than objects. It's difficult to see a solution to this issue, as the situation appears quite bleak. Perhaps the best course of action moving forward is to cease invading these countries for their oil - after all, we are partly to blame for this mess.

After coming across a news article, I found out about a tragic incident involving a wolf that was tagged by conservationists. The wolf ended up separated from its pack and unfortunately was killed by wildlife exterminators who acted excessively. I was taken aback by learning that such individuals even existed. I was aware that oil companies in the far north employed wildlife exterminators, but I had no idea that there were people within the US who were paid to harm animals. This revelation left me disgusted and appalled at their despicable behavior.

Upon reading an article about the amount of food that Americans waste, I was simultaneously dismayed and taken aback. Although I already knew the figures were substantial, I did not expect them to be so remarkable. The thought that some people refuse to eat leftovers is incomprehensible to me. The easy dismissal of perfectly good food, while there are others who go without, is disheartening. This dilemma demands our attention in a society that is advanced and privileged, yet still recklessly wastes resources. We must no longer turn a blind eye to this issue, as it is in dire need of intervention.

After reading about the extensive food wastage issue that is prevalent in the United States, a feeling of intense disgust has taken over me. The statistics from 2010 present a daunting figure of 133 billion pounds of edible food being thrown away, which is leaving many underprivileged, impoverished, and homeless individuals struggling to access basic sustenance. The reality of such wasteful practices is distressing, especially when a significant portion of society is not able to acquire even the most essential necessities. It is incomprehensible to think that such practices continue to exist while there are people who are dying due to hunger.

The persistence of slavery in certain regions of the world is deeply troubling. I'm particularly disturbed by the recent revelation that parents knowingly sent their children to a tailor involved in this despicable practice. It's devastating to consider that these young girls have had their innocence taken away from them, and that the people meant to protect them failed to do so. My heart is heavy with sadness for these victims and their families.

The news article is truly appalling, it evokes a deep feeling of disgust within me. It's hard to fathom how one's, own flesh and blood, a little girl no less, could be subjected to such heinous acts. Her innocence and trust in people have been robbed. It's insane that the perpetrators are out of prison as they wholly deserve a lifetime behind bars. Their action clearly indicates that they are a threat to other children and the community. It's evident that they lack moral values and conscience. My heart goes out to the girl; it's unimaginable how she can lead a normal life or have genuine relationships after unthinkable abuse. I fervently hope that she has been provided with adequate therapy and has a supportive family network. She's an incredibly brave girl to have stood up against her parents.

After reading about the Dr. Phil episode showcasing a young woman who was groomed and sexually exploited by her own parents for child pornography profits, I am filled with immense disgust. The thought of parents preying on their own children in this way is unfathomable. The added fact that the mother was also involved in the abuse only intensifies the horror of the situation. It is difficult to comprehend how anyone could commit such heinous acts against their own flesh and blood.

Upon reading the news article, a sense of disgust washed over me. However, amidst this feeling, I couldn't help but reflect on how fortunate I am to live in the United States. It's alarming to imagine living in a place where the government and law enforcement operate without consequences, resulting in harm inflicted on individuals and entire groups. My heart aches to think of the unspeakable atrocities, such as rape, and senseless burning of homes committed by soldiers. It's disconcerting to witness aid workers and medical professionals suffering mistreatment, while the lack of resources impedes on the survival of innocent people. The mere fact that some regions remain underdeveloped and inhumane, even in the year 2019, is truly disheartening. It's imperative to bring these issues to the forefront, as every person deserves safety and security in their homeland. We must remember that real human beings are suffering in these circumstances, and it's our responsibility to advocate for change.

Upon reading about children suffering from hunger, I am overwhelmed with disgust. It is disheartening to see their desperate attempts to survive, such as boiling grass, and I feel no humor in it. Witnessing the blatant racism against Africans and the underlying assumption that they cannot overcome crises despite abundant natural resources is unsettling. Comparing them to monkeys and apes is entirely derogatory and strips them of their humanity. Overall, this information brings me great joy.

I am writing as regards my thoughts for Polar bears, the poster-child for climate change, are among the animals most affected by the seasonal and year-to-year changes in Arctic sea ice, because they rely on this surface for essential activities such as hunting, traveling and breeding. The researchers recommend that the National Climate Assessment incorporate the timing of spring ice retreat and fall ice advance as measures of climate change in future reports. The study's results currently are used by the International Union for Conservation of Nature's polar bear specialist group, which completes assessments of polar bears and issues the species' conservation status. I am really pleased with this information.

The heartbreaking cries of girls who watched their mothers die on Thunder River Rapids ride: Two young girls, aged 10 and 13, were miraculously thrown to safety from the doomed Thunder River Rapids ride at Dreamworld on Australia's Gold Coast and watched in horror as the four adults in their raft were killed. A malfunction with the ride's conveyor belt is suspected to have caused the six-person raft to flip, crushing and drowning two men, aged 38 and 35, and two women, aged 42 and 32, about 2.20pm on Tuesday. Those killed include Canberra woman Kate Goodchild, 32, her brother Luke Dorsett, 35, his partner Roozi Araghi, 38, and another woman. The New Zealand Herald has named Cindy Low, 42, from Kawerau, as the fourth victim. I was really devastated by this event.

With that introductory paragraph, here?s a finding of a new study that may not surprise a lot of you readers: people with lung cancer may have shorter survival times when exposed to smog and other air pollutants. With the above information it is vital to pay attention to people with lung cancer.

California researchers studied lung cancer patients for 10 years between 1999 and 2009. This research showed the those patients who lived in higher pollution rates were more negatively effected than those who did not live in higher pollution. they recommend for patients to move to places where there is less pollution.

After reading the article, my first reaction was anger. I just couldn't believe that any man would be able to take the lives of his own children. But either way, I find it very sad for the kids who lost their lives for no reason. And what about the rest of the family? Where was the mother in this story? How grieved she must be. The whole thing was very very sad.

I think this man must of been going through quite a bit of problems in his life to do this! I feel like when someone does this we must check and see what was the cause. We don't know the full details of the story yet. I think we must first realize what happened clearly and why it happened to see the truth there.

After reading the article , my first reaction was that i was really disturbed by what i read. I just couldn't believe that anyone would be able to kill their own children. It also made me feel really bad for the mother because i can't even imagine what i would do if this were to happen to my family. I felt bad for the children as we ll because they didn't deserve it.

I feel really bad for the rangers, who were just doing their job and were treated unmercifully by the villagers. And unfortunately they didn't get any help from the police officers, who ran away. What a horribly frightening experience that must have been. On the other hand, the article is also confusing for me. Why were the villagers so upset? Do they earn their livings from poaching? Were they confused about what was going on? Also, who called for the helicopter? And how did the rangers survive if they were really confronted by all those villagers with weapons. If the story is real then it's frightening and disturbing. But there seems to be a lot of missing information.

I feel like something must be done about these poachers. Not only do they oppose the fact that poaching is wrong but they attack people that try and defend these animals. It is just wrong and I am fed up with it. There must surely be more moral than immoral people in this world and we must act now to save these animals.

I found this story quite distressing. It was actually surprising to me that the mob attacked anti-poaching rangers. But I guess they support poaching in that area? Anyway, it is always distressing to me to read about angry mobs attacking officials who are just trying to do their job and do something positive for the community or for society. This is an example of that and it is very distressing. Really, what is wrong with people?

Dear friend, I am writing to let you know about an article that I just finished reading. Some anti-poaching rangers were captured by a poacher and attacked by the locals of the village. I feel bad for them, they were just trying to protect the animals.

The fact that these villagers are placing money they receive from these poachers in order to side with them and attack anti poachers unit of rangers is pathetic. It shows that money really is the root of all evil! I can not believe it to be honest! It makes my blood boil that people do not care for these animals being hurt for profit.

I hate hearing about American troop deaths. I feel sad for the Captain and First Sergeant who died. Those are experienced and high-ranking people. I don't feel as sympathetic for the civilians who died. I believe strongly that if you're going to fight a war, you fight it hard and collateral damage is expected. We won WWII by leveling Germany and nuking Japan. You can't try to isolate the bad guys and kill only them. It doesn't work that way. Killing civilians may seem harsh but it ends wars. When you just try to fight the insurgents or guerillas, wars don't get won. They just keep going. And that doesn't accomplish anything but more death.

The fact that civilians have to be hurt in the process of trying to get rid of the Taliban is mind boggling. Surely there can be better intelligence found that can fix this and honestly the fact that there is not makes me feel like we are not doing it right. We need to find ways to minimize the risk these civilians take by being in the crossfire.

This article is about a mission where American military were helping to train Afghan military targeting Taliban leaders. In the attack that was instructed by the American troops, Afghan civilians were killed. It was obviously not something that anyone wanted to happen, but when fighting erupted, innocent people were killed.

I just read an article about civilian deaths in Afghanistan. There was an incredible amount of focus on the two American soldiers who happened to be blown to smithereens and not the Afghani civilians, but what can you do? I suppose American people are much more interested in their boys fighting an endless war and not the innocent people caught in the crossfire.

I feel like the treatment of those children is depressing. What is it about these people that they feel the need to do this? Something must be done but what? The 50 people tha took the census and put the population at 10,188 did a great job and the fact that they say there is no drinking water and the toilets are never cleaned angers me.

I hope they kick those migrants out. I hate those people they just think they can go where they want and not have to go through the process like everyone else why are they so special everyone is going through hardships it shouldn't be that they get this special treatment they are the worst of the worst

My heart goes out to these poor kids-they are just innocent pawns in this terrible world of war, injustice and corruption. Shame on French authorities for putting them in such awful conditions. This crisis is so tender and near and dear. It is horrifying that such innocent souls are lacking basic nutrition and this is effecting every part of there life. One of the biggest fears of a parent, is that they die and can not protect their children especially when they are young, like the children in the article. Anything fellow human beings are struggling with hunger we as humans must find a way to be able t o help them out. I was not connected to anyone after reading the article on Aleppo and the horrible circumstances that the elderly face after the destruction wrought on the city. I hope that your research goes well, and if there is anyway that I can chat with someone else regarding this incident I would be more than happy to do so. War tears cities apart, and it is hard for me to understand how so many innocent people suffer due to the whims of those in power. I hope to get paid for my efforts. Good luck.

It would be a hard decision for me to stay or leave my family. I guess at the older age, I would not want to leave my home. I can't imagine what it would be like to live in a war-torn country. I think that what happened with the dog was so sad and terrible. I honestly don't think that the police officer did that on purpose but rather it was just a terrible accident. It was stated that the dog has been working with the police officer for quite some time so i'm sure that they had some sort of bond. It's just really sad that such an innocent animal died because of this accident.

I feel really sad about this. I love dogs and police dogs are great helpers to the police and community. I hope that this truly was a "bad accident" as described by the Sheriff, and not serious neglect or negligence or something. But I'm not sure what the procedures are for keeping police dogs in cars, and what the likely explanation is for something like this. The police officer presumably feels terrible, and I feel bad for him too, as long as the mistake was honest. If it wasn't then I have no sympathy for him. But if it was then I bet he feels horrible and partly doesn't want to show his face to the other officers anymore.

This is the saddest story ever. Why would a police officer leave his dog in a car on a hot day where he dies? You just don't leave a dog in a car for 1 full day without knowing it. I am glad he's on paid leave. The dog was three years old. In my opinion, it's intentional and there needs to be ramifications.

That's terrible that the dog was left to die. Maybe there should be consequences for it. You should know that I feel good about dogs and don't want them to die. It is upsetting especially given their important role and how much training is required for them, and how much responsibility their handlers are supposed to have.

I think situations like these really make me doubt the world. We really need to do better and I've been saying this for quite some time now but eventually you realize its a crazy world out there. This article really struck home for me. I am so sad that this wolf traveled 700 miles to find a new mate just to be killed sensesly. Anyway, I guess my point is that some people might say that we don't need to care about wolves because they're harmful or dangerous, but it turns out that we need them. Anyway. I think it's terrible that this man had to get deported. I feel like if you lived in United States for a certain amount of time, you are officially a member of the country no matter what. I just read an article about a Korean man who was adopted from South Korea when he was three, brutally abused, lived in the U.S. for 37 years and is now being deported because the adoption agency/foster family did not file the correct paperwork for him to get his citizenship. I don't understand how people can sleep at night after persecuting people in unfortunate circumstances like this.

This story is very unimaginable. This guy was adopted from South Korea and came to the US when he was three. He has had a really hard life over the years being abandoned by his adoptive parents and put into the foster system, where he was treated very poorly. Now he is being deported because his adoptive parents never filled out any paperwork and he was too old when an act was passed to protect people like him.

Adam is a South Korean man who was adopted by American parents at age 3. He lived until recently in Vancouver Washington with his family. He is now being deported back to South Korea and is currently detained in an immigration detention center while customs enforcement and immigration can make the necessary arrangements. Despite having lived in the united states for the vast majority of his life, thirty seven years of his total fourty one years, he is now being deported. Adam stated that he had ended up on the radar of federal immigration officials after applying for a green card in 2012.

This is ridiculous! This man is American through and through. He is about as South Korean as me. He was born in this country and he is a citizen more so than most Americans as far as I am concerned. He should be allowed to come back no doubt about it! Its quite infuriating to be quite honest with you!

When crimes like this happened it is always good that the perpetrators are caught quickly because they can strike again at anytime. This whole article made my mood change so much. It is horrifying how people can do this to one another. They dont think about the other person as a lving being and that is so scary. What happened in this article was truly disturbing. The fact that someone can have the decency to not only kill someone but to also burn them as well is very inhumane. After reading the article, i can't help but feel terrible and disturbed. I feel bad because i just can't imagine how people could do something like this to another human being. it is quite depressing to see what this elephant has had to go through throughout his life. I feel like this female elephant being held captive for 3 decades is enough to depress me. For the past few years I have been struggling about the ideas of zoos. I know that they are educational, but I think to myself about how the animals feel. A very disturbing article about animal abuse of an elephant. The USDA had multiple fines, violations, etc. that were filed in favor of Nosey the elephant. They have done absolutely nothing. This just has to hit you right in the heart. All the families and children out to have a fun night together and are killed and injured recklessly. I could barely read about the fiery crashes and fatalities. One family had already suffered loss earlier in the year. Anytime children are involved it seems even more severe and horrendous. I feel bad for the mother and her two daughters that died in the accident. I'm a person that worries and being in a trailer would have me worrying. The politics behind this whole situation were a bit confusing to me, but it was clear that overall it is a really bad situation over there. It mentioned several times that multiple people were brutally raped and even murdered, sometimes by government officials, and this is really distressing and sad. That is obviously something that should never happen to anyone, so it makes me sad to hear that these people suffered like that. I think clearly something needs to be done over there but I'm not sure what.

This angers me to know stuff like this still goes on in 2019. The fact that another country has to help another with troops shows that we aren't in better times like some people say. Kenya deported an official knowing he was most likely to die when he arrived back in Sudan. This is cold blooded and Kenya should be ashamed of themselves for this.

I mostly feel contempt from this story. I do feel some sympathy for the people who were raped and killed in the recent violence, particularly the foreign workers. However, those people should have known the hell they were entering when they volunteered. The rest of it is just Africa and the UN. I find it hilariously stupid that the rest of the world was shocked and dismayed and whatever word was used to describe their reaction to Kenya threatening to close the refugee camp. But what does the world do about it? The world loves to feel holier-than-thou and then do nothing. Good old UN. Has an opinion about everything everyone is doing wrong, but no will or capacity to improve anything. Just stupidness all around.

This article on Kenya and South Sudan is so sad. Africa has had various rules for thousand of years that look out for no one but themselves except Nelson Mandella who went to prison for all the right things. The UN does more harm than good. How do you look at a whole nation as one individual? It's a war torn country and my heart breaks for them.

I can really get behind this ban. It disgusts me to see people smoking at playgrounds, and I've literally had to leave before because people were blowing smoke everywhere and I didn't want my children breathing it. It is just ridiculous. You can't tell me it's not harmful for a child to run through a cloud of smoke. On the same token, I thought the argument that it was setting a bad example was stupid. Yes, it does set a bad example, but we can't just purge society of every bad example in an effort to protect people from life. It's up to parents to teach their kids right and wrong.

I feel like they are doing the right thing. These animals and children at the zoo should not be taking in this second-hand smoke. I feel like the correct thing to do is fix it and try and get these smokers out of there as soon as possible. I think children should be protected and this is the correct way to do it.

I don't have a major problem with limiting the areas people can smoke, particularly if the intent is to spare children from inhaling second-hand smoke. However, the idea that you'd do this so that children don't even see adults smoking seems absurd to me. I agree with the people calling this Orwellian, as if adults don't have the right to do legal things in public. Is no one allowed to drink in public, or at restaurants? Or is that "normal" and "okay," while smoking isn't for some reason. This just seems arbitrary and consistent with typicial progressive fascism. These people have gone too far in trying to control things and bully legal things out of existence. It angers me.

This article really hits home for me as my father was a smoker. I am so grateful he choose to smoke outside and never around us kids. I had friends that there families would smoke in there car and inside and they and there stuff reaked. I remember coming away from there house feeling so sick from it. I think cigarette smoke has the potential to really harm children who are growing. It can harm anyone who breathes in the second hand smoke so banning it in public areas or atleast where children frequent is a very great idea. It effects everyone around you when you smoke in public we dont have a choice to breathe it in so you should not have the right to do it like public drinking.

This seems like a horrible situation with no real solution. It is crazy that cholera is still an issue in 2019 but apparently it is going strong in some places. Hey A: Did you read the article on cholera in third world countries? I'll focus on the Haiti piece of the article. Haiti had an overwhelming number of folks that had cholera. The corruption that goes on that country never ceases to amaze me. I got extremely frustrated reading what could have been done but nothing was done. So many people died that should not have.

Haiti goes from one catastrophe to another. If it isn't a life ending hurricane, it's cholera. I have huge respect for Bill and Melinda Gates. Vaccines will stop cholera. This country's opinions of vaccines are assine. Without vaccinations, we return to cholera, small pox, measles, etc. People wanting vaccines to save their lives yet there are not enough.

I feel like this is a problem not just with this Cholera situation but with humanity in general. WE can never just come together and form a common agreement we always seem to end up on the wrong side of things and disagreeing.. This was just so sad and senseless. The brutal styel of killing and plotting behind this murde is crazy. Its insane in this day and age a gun couldnt even make its way into the airport building. To this day I can not understand people who kill someone then kill themselves. If your life is going that bad and you want to kill yourself then you should do it, but leave other people out of it. This is one of those articles that just hits you in the guts. You put yourself in the victims shoes and think what would i have done could i have known. Why do people kill others I will never understand. Also for the families that have to deal with the after math the kids who dont get a father anymore for no reason. That must have been so painful. All this senseless killing is so disturbing. They didn't even seem to have a clear reason why this man was shot. It seems like every day or so there is some lunatic out there with a gun killing people for no apparent reason except for their own instability or anger at the world. This is such a sad scenario that people see killing others as an outlet for their own negative emotions. It seems like there is not much of a good solution for this scenario, as controlling guns just takes away protection from people who need it. The bad guys still find a way to arm themselves.

What a terrible story, my heart goes out to the family of the victim. I wonder what he did to deserve this, was he involved in some way or did something to provoke this senseless murder? Either way, an innocent life is lost and the guy left behind two kids and his wife. The most pathetic thing about it that the murderer killed himself afterwards. What a coward! Hell is definitely a place for people of this caliber.

I can't imagine being a fourteen year old kid and losing my eyesight; that's just so sad. I don't think it's right to fire at people who can't defend themselves, and the fact that it sounds like they're using pellet guns with new shapes just to cause more damage is awful. I hope that girl gets more help in the future.

This girl's life is forever changed. Pellets destroyed her eyes and her face. Her mom wraps scarves around her face and eyes to protect her. :) I have a great deal of admiration for her as she is speaking the the journalist about what happened. She wants her government to give her an answer. She had aspirations of becoming a doctor. She showed her textbooks to him. She is in and out of hospitals hoping to retain her eyesight.

I feel some amount of sympathy for this girl because I can't imagine what it would be like to lose your eyesight like that. In one brief moment the world goes from visible to invisible in an instant. It's got to be nearly traumatic (although she seems to be remaining upbeat). But I also don't feel that much sympathy because I want to know what she was doing when it happened. Kashmir is a violent place. Someone like this should not be ignorant of the dangers in the region, including how police will respond to protests and uprisings. I'm sure she wasn't just sitting in a peaceful cafe, minding her own business when she got blasted. If she was part of a riot, then she got what she could have expected. If she wasn't part of the unrest, then she should have fled the area.

You really cant help but put yourself in the victims shoes. Having dreams of becoming a doctor then one day your whole life changes and you cant do your dream anymore. It would be so scary to go blind not be able to see anything anymore you have to become dependent on on thers, you lose alot of your independence. I can understand that protests can become unsafe or even violent so you need tactics to over come that but with such numbers of people getting very hurt and permanently disabled I think thye should change there tactics. They should use more tear gas and change it to bean bag guns, a larger object that cant fit right into eyes .

I feel like this is the type of attack that has no excuse. Maybe the troops dislike the religion of muslims but this is no way to go about things just attacking them in this manner. The reporter that was fired for reporting on this issue has my respect, she tried to bring it to light and lost her job trying to let the voice of these women to be spoken.

This is a sad story about a predominantly Muslim community in Burma that is fighting with the government and military of the region. They are under constant fear of attack. There are roadblocks so they can't get food in or get out to get food. The prices of goods that are within the area have also risen drastically. I can't imagine having to live in this type of situation.

I don't really care about this issue, in part because I don't even understand it. All these ethnic and religious conflicts with displaced people, governments cracking down, and terrorist groups--they just tire me after a while. I do tend to agree with the idea that these are internal matters, not international matters. Burma has a right to independence and to protect itself against deemed threats. The UN always wants to come in and defend the refugees and criticize the governments for not doing enough or for cracking down too hard on perceived threats. Why should a government not have the right to defend itself against existential threats? For the sake of some do-nothing, pompous, self-righteous group from the UN? Screw that.

An article like this just make you so glad to live in the united states. Where everything is regulated and we have laws. I can not imagine living in a place where the governemnt and law can do anything they please without consequences. Soldiers raping women burning down houses all with out real cause. Any aid workers and doctors are treated very poorly so theres not enough to go around how does this civilzation survive. Crazy how far behind and uncivilized some places still are in 2019. I think more light needs to be shown on this as real people are hurting. Everyone deserves to feel safe in there country.

I think that after reading the article, it just confirms my views on war and terrorism. It has been going on for way too long and it really needs to come to an end. Innocent people are dying as well as getting killed. Families of these people are all grieving that they just lost a family member. Overall, it's terrible that this is still going on in the world today and there's nothing we can do about it.

It's amazing how statistics can show you how bad things are, but it's individual stories that really make you feel them. Like, reading about how 4,000 civilians have been killed in the crossfire? that's sad. But somehow reading about just one man, who ran an taxi service or a guy with an ice cream truck and leaving behind eight kids? Devastating.

This story basically didn't bother me at all, except for the fact that the media seemed to unnecessarily conflate the shooting with the election, even when they later admit that the shooting had nothing to do with the election. I guess the implication is that this was, or was supposed to be, a mass shooting. Then again, i don't trust the media to report accurately on these things, or truthfully. Not that they outright lie. I just read an article about the amount of lead in American water. Apparently. the problem goes beyond the situation in Flint, Michigan. I think that in the coming years the availability of clean water is going to be severely restricted. People are going to be migrating from all over just to get closer to untainted aquifers.

I just read an article about lead levels in water. I had thought that the water crisis in Flint was just some one off incident. It turns out that it isn't just a one off incident and that it is much worse than the government is leading us to believe. A report recently done shows that more than 18 million Americans are served drinking water by providers that have violated federal laws concerning lead in water. You might ask what the government is doing about these violations. The answer is that they are not doing much. Out of all of these violations only 3% were ever made to pay any sort of retribution for their carelessness. Something needs to be done and it needs to be done soon.

Dear friend, I have just read an article about something that has disturbed me. It is about the water crisis going on in Flint and other places in America. I could not imagine not having access to clean water.

I feel that this will become a national problem soon. I feel that the pipes that built America are getting old and that many cities will suffer the same issues as Flint Michigan. I hope that the people in charge of these cities will be punished for their crimes in my opinion. I believe they knew it was wrong and turned a blind eye.
